ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: In fact, man will be clear proof against himself
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: In fact man is a witness against himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: But lo, man is well aware of himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: In fact, people are well-aware of their own soul
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: In fact, man himself is keeping an eye on his state of affairs!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Nay! Man will be well informed about himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Nay! man is evidence against himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: nay, man shall be a clear proof against himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Oh, but man is a telling witness against himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: Indeed, man shall be a witness against himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Aye! man against himself shall be an enlightenment.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: Indeed, man is a witness to himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Nay, man will be evidence against himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Nay! Man will be a witness against himself [as his body parts (skin, hands, legs, etc.) will speak about his deeds].
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: He shall be a clear proof against himself,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: And man will be evidence against himself.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Rather, man, against himself, will be a witness,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [75:14] Rather man has insight into his [own] soul, for his limbs will speak of his deeds (the hā’ [sc. the tā’ marbūta in basīratun] is for hyperbole), and so he must be requited,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Oh, but man) 'Adiyy Ibn Rabi'ah and others (is a telling witness against himself) He says: he will testify against his own self,
